text:
Question! Whenever you take notes on a paper, what sort of sections do you have? Generally, in my notes I have found it useful to categorize components into the following:

1. General Insights
2. Methods
3. Conclusions
4. Themes/topics
How do you all take notes on papers? If you could provide examples of your notes, that would be great to see! Thank you. :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Maybe Zettelkasten (<https://www.zettelkasten.org/>) is suitable for you. Basically, when taking notes in a Zettelkasten, you try to avoid assuming any structure and just link everything together via a graph. So, when I take notes, I only get the ideas which I want to "remember", and I try to link that to previous topics that I know of. It takes some discipline to have a Zettelkasten, but you can always store a random thought and *most importantly* you can actually find back anything you have stored in the past.

text: I recommend using paper. Write down recaps of the most important sections. Then you can throw away the notes. Having to scribble the findings will cause you to rephrase it to be more concise (because people are lazy), and having to rephrase it is great for learning and remembering

text: I don't have a very structured way to ingest papers (I don't think it is possible even because there is no one structure which fits all papers). Usually, when reading papers I'm looking for something specific. If I find that, then I'll add it somewhere in my ZK. If I see something else which might be interesting, then I'll add that somewhere else in the ZK.

text: I store all my academic sources in Zotero (<https://www.zotero.org>), and use Zotero’s built-in notes to write down key aspects or original ideas. That way, the notes always go hand in hand with their associated paper. Naturally, using Zotero also comes with a ****load of other benefits, which I will gladly describe if you leave me alone in a room for too long.

text:
I really don't read enough thoroughly anymore. Most of my reading these days is instrumental - generally I need a particular method or to confirm something I think I know (and a citation), so I'm basically just scanning/deep diving until I find that thing.

In grad school when I was doing deep dives, I had different highlighter colors for (1) background, (2) data / observations, (3) methods, (4) conclusions. I'd write a summary sentence for each figure and one for the paper as a whole.
